descriptionSet.description: In this movie poster for the movie "Laila Majnu", released in 1945, a woman is sitting on a rock and leaning against a man who is crouching beside her. He holds her shoulder as he gives her a loving glance. Both are wearing jewellery and gypsy-like outfits.

inscription.text: A stamp which reads: Bengal Films Exchange, Calcutta. Bengal Films Corporation. Movie Arts. [on backside?] (ja)
Hind Pictures Present: Laila Majnu. A Bengal release.Starring: Swarnlata, Nazir and Gope.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: In this movie poster for the movie "Laila Majnu", released in 1945, a woman is sitting on a rock and leaning against a man who is crouching beside her. He holds her shoulder as he gives her a loving glance. Both are wearing jewellery and gypsy-like outfits. (gs/sp)

related hyperlinks: http://cineplot.com/gobindram-filmography/, last accessed 2012-04-01, mention of the film and main crew (sp)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The perennially popular story of Laila Majnu (Nayyar & Nazir, 1945) peddled romantic fantasies set in garden terraces. (Rosie Thomas) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Two genres dominated Indiaâs B-movie circuit in the 1950s: stunt and fantasy films â otherwise referred to as âfightingâ and âmagicâ (or âjadooâ) films. The former refers to all manner of action films, which invariably drew openly on the Hollywood âlowâ genres popular in India since the silent era. Indiaâs fantasy films, on the other hand, were spun around magical and wondrous happenings in a quasi-Arabian Islamicate setting, most drawing loosely on oral and literary traditions of the Arabian Nights. (Rosie Thomas) (gs)
related literature: Said, Edward 1995. "Orientalism". London: Penguin Books. (gs)
related hyperlinks: Thomas, Rosie 2010. "Still Magic. An Aladdin's Cave of 1950s B-Movie Fantasy" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/103/index.html, last accessed 2010-11-22. (gs)
